elements.title: Call-Echo Information Hierarchy: Mirror the Agent's Language and Order on Every Platform Page
elements.problem: Diane explicitly states she wants to 'read the whole website' (15:59) before proceeding, creating a critical handoff where the platform must independently replicate the cognitive ease that Robert built conversationally. The call delivered value propositions in a specific order using specific words: payment guarantee ('We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you,' 04:36), damage matching ('if the damage exceeds the $500, we will match for the same amount,' 05:28), no host fees ('all our income comes from markup to the guests,' 11:28). If the website presents these same propositions in different words, in a different order, or buried in different page sections, Kahneman's illusions-of-truth research predicts Diane will not recognize them as the same claims she already accepted. The information hierarchy of the website must echo the information hierarchy of the call, because the call is the host's first mental model of what this platform is.
elements.solution: Structure every host-facing platform page so that the primary information layer uses the same phrases, in the same conceptual order, that agents use on sales calls. Specifically: (1) The homepage or host landing page should lead with the three guarantees in call order: payment collection guarantee, damage deposit matching, zero host fees. (2) Each guarantee should use the agent's conversational phrasing as the headline, with formal/legal language available only as a secondary expandable layer. (3) The onboarding welcome screen should open with the specific value propositions Robert mentioned, not generic platform features. (4) Create an explicit mapping between the call script and the website copy, and treat the call language as the canonical version -- the website adapts to the call, not the reverse.

evidence.quote: You don't have to start the account. Anyway, if I want to, I want to read the whole website.
evidence.insight: Diane will compare what she reads on the website against what she heard Robert say. This is an explicit verification intent. The website's information hierarchy must match the call's information hierarchy for the verification to produce cognitive ease rather than cognitive strain.

evidence.quote: A reliable way to make people believe in falsehoods is frequent repetition, because familiarity is not easily distinguished from truth. The familiarity of one phrase in the statement sufficed to make the whole statement feel familiar, and therefore true.
evidence.insight: The website's truth-feeling depends on phrase-level recognition, not concept-level comprehension. If the website says 'payment intermediation service' instead of 'we guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you,' the concept is the same but the truth-feeling is lost because the specific phrase is unfamiliar.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, How to Write a Persuasive Message
evidence.quote: Do not use complex language where simpler language will do... couching familiar ideas in pretentious language is taken as a sign of poor intelligence and low credibility.
evidence.insight: Elevating conversational call language into formal website copy does not merely lose familiarity -- it actively signals low credibility. The host interprets the register shift as evasion or pretension, not professionalism.

evidence.quote: We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you. So you don't have to worry about collecting the payment from the guests... if the damage exceeds the $500, we will match for the same amount.
evidence.insight: These are the canonical phrases for the two core guarantees. They were delivered in plain conversational English and passed Diane's System 1 filter during the call. The website must present these exact phrases -- or phrases within one register level -- as primary headlines, not as buried fine print.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the three core guarantees in call language (payment guarantee, damage matching, no host fees). Secondary: how the model works (commuters, divorced parents, complementary schedules). Tertiary: legal/formal details expandable on demand. The hierarchy mirrors the call's information delivery order because that is the order in which the host's mental model was constructed.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Layer 1 (immediate, above the fold): guarantee headlines in call language. Layer 2 (one click/scroll): concrete examples and scenarios matching the ones Robert used. Layer 3 (expandable): formal terms, legal language, supplemental agreement details. The host should never encounter Layer 3 language before encountering Layer 1 language.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 value propositions visible simultaneously on any single screen. Each proposition expressed in 15 words or fewer at the headline level. No legal or technical terminology in the primary information layer.
scan_order: Payment guarantee headline in call language
Damage deposit matching headline in call language
exclude: Legal terminology in the primary scan path
Platform feature lists that were not mentioned on the call
Industry jargon ('supplemental agreement,' 'damage protection policy') without the plain-language equivalent appearing first
Generic testimonials from unknown hosts (Diane trusts her own evaluation, not strangers' endorsements)

elements.title: Scenario-Based Pricing Disclosure: Sequential Concrete Examples, Not a Multi-Variable Matrix
elements.problem: Robert's pricing explanation (12:29-13:49) is the most cognitively demanding part of the call: variable rates by nights-per-week, different prices for 4-night versus 2-night stays, complementary schedule matching, and per-month versus per-week versus per-night structures. On the call, this complexity was manageable because Robert walked through it as a sequence of concrete scenarios with specific numbers ('If you have a person four nights, how much per day... and how much per day if you will have two nights'). Diane responded with confident familiarity ('I just did all of that for years... I'm familiar,' 14:20), but Kahneman's framework warns this confidence is an illusion of truth -- she pattern-matched 'nightly pricing' to her 15 years of hotel-style rentals without engaging with the novel elements. When she encounters the pricing interface, if it presents all options simultaneously as a form or matrix, the conversational scaffolding disappears and the cognitive load spikes. A multi-variable pricing matrix is the opposite of how Robert explained it.
elements.solution: Structure the pricing interface as a sequential scenario walkthrough, mirroring how Robert explained it on the call. (1) Start with one question: 'How do you want to rent this place?' with three clear options: full-time (per month), alternating weeks (per week), or part of the week (per night). (2) Based on the host's selection, present one follow-up scenario at a time. For part-of-week: 'If a guest books 4 nights per week, what would you charge per night?' followed separately by 'If a guest books only 2 nights per week, what would you charge per night?' (3) After input, show a concrete projection: 'At these rates, a 4-night guest pays you $200/week. A 2-night guest pays you $120/week.' (4) Only after the host confirms understanding, show the full pricing summary with all scenarios together. Never start with the summary.

evidence.quote: If somebody says, I want only every week, but Monday through Thursday... then we will say, okay, how much per day you would want. If you have a person four nights, how much per day... and how much per day if you will have two nights.
evidence.insight: Robert presented pricing as a sequential conversation: one scenario at a time, each building on the last. The pricing interface must replicate this sequential structure. Presenting all pricing options simultaneously destroys the scaffolding that made the verbal explanation comprehensible.

evidence.quote: I just did all of that for years... I'm familiar.
evidence.insight: Diane's confidence is based on pattern-matching to her prior nightly-rental experience, not on genuine comprehension of Split Lease's variable-rate model. The pricing interface must surface the differences before the host confirms, using concrete dollar projections that make the novel mechanics visible.

evidence.quote: The familiarity of one phrase in the statement sufficed to make the whole statement feel familiar, and therefore true.
evidence.insight: The phrase 'per night' triggers false familiarity with the entire pricing model. The interface must introduce a brief moment of productive friction -- a concrete scenario that reveals the variable-rate structure -- so the host engages System 2 with the novel aspects before misconfiguring prices.

evidence.quote: Performance was better with the bad font. Cognitive strain, whatever its source, mobilizes System 2, which is more likely to reject the intuitive answer suggested by System 1.
evidence.insight: A brief, deliberate friction point at pricing confirmation (showing real dollar projections that might not match expectations) is beneficial. It mobilizes System 2 to verify the host's intuitive pricing assumptions before they become binding configuration.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the rental mode question (full-time / alternating weeks / part-of-week). Secondary: one pricing scenario at a time with specific numbers. Tertiary: the complete pricing summary showing all scenarios together. The hierarchy moves from simple to complex, mirroring the call's conversational scaffolding.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Step 1: Single choice (rental mode). Step 2: One rate question per scenario, presented sequentially. Step 3: Dollar projection for each scenario. Step 4: Confirmation with full summary. The host never sees Step 4 before completing Steps 1-3. Each step is self-contained and completable in under 30 seconds.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 pricing question per screen/step. Maximum 2 numbers visible at any decision point (the rate and the resulting weekly/monthly total). No more than 3 pricing scenarios total for the initial setup. The pricing summary appears only after all individual scenarios are set.
scan_order: Current scenario rate input with concrete example
Dollar projection showing weekly and monthly totals
exclude: Multi-variable pricing matrices or tables during initial setup
All pricing options displayed simultaneously before the host has selected a rental mode
Abstract pricing concepts without concrete dollar amounts
Rate comparison charts between different occupancy patterns (these are useful later, not during initial pricing setup)

elements.title: Guest Profile Richness Architecture: Compensate for Lost Physical Evaluation with Structured Digital Abundance
elements.problem: Diane's 15 years of hosting UN diplomats involved in-person guest evaluation. Her instinctive question at 09:48 ('So I don't need them first to see?') reveals that her mental model of guest vetting is physical: seeing the person, reading body language, assessing trustworthiness face-to-face. The platform restricts direct communication until the lease is signed ('people cannot communicate except through our site,' 08:47), and substitutes a Zoom meeting option. But the proposal management interface must bridge the gap between Diane's rich physical evaluation mental model and the digital proposal format. If the guest profile feels thin -- a name, a few lines of text, no photo or context -- the information poverty will trigger the vigilance-and-suspicion cluster that Kahneman associates with cognitive strain. The guest profile must feel as informationally rich as meeting someone in person.
elements.solution: Design the guest proposal profile to provide informational richness that compensates for the absence of physical meeting. (1) Lead with the guest's stated purpose: 'Commuter, works in Manhattan Mon-Thu' or 'Divorced parent, sees children every other weekend.' Purpose is what Diane evaluated first with her diplomat tenants -- why someone needs the space. (2) Show verified information prominently: employment verification status, ID verification status, prior Split Lease history if any. Verification badges serve as digital substitutes for in-person trust signals. (3) Include the guest's proposed schedule in visual calendar format, not text. The schedule is concrete and factual, producing cognitive ease where biographical text might feel vague. (4) Offer the Zoom meeting option as a prominent call-to-action, not a buried link. For hosts like Diane who are accustomed to in-person evaluation, the Zoom option is not a nice-to-have -- it is the bridge between her old mental model and the new one. (5) Show the guest's message to the host, in the guest's own words, prominently. A human voice in text produces more cognitive ease than platform-generated summaries.

evidence.quote: So I don't need them first to see?
evidence.insight: Diane's default is physical evaluation. The platform must provide enough digital information to satisfy the same assessment needs that a physical meeting would serve: Who is this person? Why do they need my space? Can I trust them?

evidence.quote: Nobody does it blindly, we always collect information about our guests and we share most information with hosts. The only thing we do not share is direct contact information.
evidence.insight: Robert promises that 'most information' is shared. The proposal interface must deliver on this promise visibly. If the guest profile shows only a name and a message, it contradicts the 'most information' claim and triggers the cognitive strain of a broken promise.

evidence.quote: When you feel strained, you are more likely to be vigilant and suspicious, invest more effort in what you are doing, feel less comfortable, and make fewer errors.
evidence.insight: An informationally thin guest profile produces cognitive strain, which pushes the host into vigilant/suspicious mode. An informationally rich profile -- purpose, verification badges, schedule, guest's own words -- produces cognitive ease, enabling the intuitive trust that leads to proposal acceptance.

evidence.quote: Good mood, intuition, creativity, gullibility, and increased reliance on System 1 form a cluster. At the other pole, sadness, vigilance, suspicion, an analytic approach, and increased effort also go together.
evidence.insight: The goal is to keep the host in the ease/intuition cluster when reviewing proposals. An informationally rich guest profile creates the positive mood state that enables intuitive acceptance. An informationally thin profile pushes the host toward the vigilance/suspicion cluster, making every proposal feel risky.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: guest's stated purpose and schedule (why they need the space, when they need it). Secondary: verification signals (ID verified, employment verified, prior platform history). Tertiary: guest's personal message and Zoom meeting option. The hierarchy mirrors in-person evaluation: first you learn why someone is there, then you verify their credibility, then you hear them speak.
elements.disclosure_pattern: All primary and secondary information visible on the proposal card without scrolling or expanding. Tertiary information (full message, Zoom scheduling) available with one action. No proposal should require clicking through to a separate profile page to access the information needed for a basic accept/decline decision.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 6 information elements on the proposal card: purpose, schedule (visual), verification status, lease term, proposed rate, and one-line message preview. Full message and meeting options available on expansion. The host should be able to evaluate a proposal in under 60 seconds.
scan_order: Zoom meeting and full profile actions
exclude: Guest's direct contact information before lease signing
Unverified biographical details that cannot be confirmed
Platform-generated personality descriptions or compatibility scores (the host trusts her own judgment, not algorithmic assessments)
Information about other proposals on the same property (creates comparison anxiety rather than evaluation focus)

elements.title: Cumulative Track Record Display: Make Every Successful Interaction Visible and Countable
elements.problem: Diane's COVID experience reveals what happens when years of successful hosting leave no visible record. She had 'pretty good people, steady' for years (06:23), but when disruptions came, there was no accumulated evidence of reliability to contextualize the failure. Each successful month had been invisible, so the failures dominated her perception. On a platform, the same dynamic applies: if payments deposit silently, uneventful stays produce no feedback, and smooth interactions leave no trace, then the first problem becomes the host's entire story about the platform. Kahneman's mere exposure research shows that repeated positive exposure builds safety signals, but only if the host is conscious of the repetition. Silent success is wasted exposure -- the host's System 1 cannot form a positive association with something it never noticed.
elements.solution: Design the active lease dashboard to make every successful interaction a visible, countable data point. (1) After every on-time payment, display a confirmation that includes a running count: 'Payment 4 of 6 received on time -- $800 deposited.' The count makes the pattern salient. (2) At the end of each lease or stay cycle, generate a brief summary card: '6/6 payments on time. 0 damage claims. $4,800 total earned.' This is the host's evidence that the platform works. (3) On the host's main dashboard, maintain a persistent 'track record' section showing cumulative stats across all properties and all leases: total payments received, on-time percentage, total earned, damage claims ratio. For a multi-property host like Diane, this compounds visibly. (4) When a negative event occurs, present it in the context of the positive history: '17 of 18 payments on time. 1 payment 3 days late -- here is what we are doing.' The positive history absorbs the negative event instead of the negative event defining the platform.

evidence.quote: COVID made the mess... I had pretty good people, steady... some moved out, didn't pay a few more months.
evidence.insight: Years of successful renting left no accumulated visible record. When the disruption came, there was nothing to weigh against it. The platform must make successful months visible so that disruptions are contextualized, not defining.

evidence.quote: We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is the core promise. Each successful payment is proof the guarantee works. But invisible proof builds less trust than visible proof. The guarantee must be actively demonstrated through visible confirmations, not merely passively honored through silent deposits.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, The Pleasure of Cognitive Ease
evidence.quote: The mere exposure effect occurs because the repeated exposure of a stimulus is followed by nothing bad. Such a stimulus will eventually become a safety signal, and safety is good.
evidence.insight: Each visible payment confirmation is an 'exposure' that builds the platform into a safety signal. But the exposure must be conscious to count. A silent bank deposit is not an exposure -- the host never associates it with the platform. A visible confirmation card with the platform's branding and a running count is an exposure.

evidence.quote: A good mood is a signal that things are generally going well, the environment is safe, and it is all right to let one's guard down.
evidence.insight: Each visible positive event reinforces the host's good mood about the platform. The cumulative effect shifts the host's default state from vigilance to ease, making renewal and re-listing a System 1 decision rather than a System 2 deliberation.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current payment status and running count (the most immediate safety signal). Secondary: lease-level summary stats (on-time rate, total earned, damage claims). Tertiary: cumulative cross-property track record. The hierarchy moves from the immediate (this month's payment) to the cumulative (all-time record), building the safety signal from specific to general.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Payment confirmations arrive proactively (push notification or email). Lease summaries appear at natural endpoints (lease completion, renewal prompt). The cumulative track record is always visible on the host dashboard without navigation. Negative events always appear within the context of the positive track record, never in isolation.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Payment confirmations: maximum 3 data points (amount, date, running count). Lease summaries: maximum 5 data points (payments on-time, total earned, damage claims, guest rating, lease duration). Dashboard track record: maximum 4 aggregate metrics visible at once. No charts or complex visualizations -- simple counts and percentages.
scan_order: Running payment count for this lease
exclude: Complex financial charts or graphs that require interpretation
Comparison with other hosts' performance
Negative event notifications that lack the context of the positive track record
Platform marketing messages embedded in payment confirmations (the confirmation should feel like a receipt, not an ad)

elements.title: Micro-Task Information Architecture: One Decision per Screen, Deep-Linked from Notification
elements.problem: Diane describes her time constraint as structural, not temporary: 'the day is never long enough' (00:49). She manages multiple properties across Manhattan and Queens. The standard platform design assumption -- that the host will sit down and complete a multi-step process in one session -- fails for this host type. Kahneman's observation that 'System 2 is lazy and mental effort is aversive' compounds with time poverty: not only is the effort aversive, but there is no time window in which to exert it. Every platform interaction that requires more than 2 minutes of focused attention or navigating through multiple pages to reach the task will be deferred indefinitely. The information architecture must accommodate a host who completes tasks in the 90-second gaps between other commitments, on a phone, while context-switching between three properties.
elements.solution: Structure every host-facing task as an atomic micro-task with its own deep link and its own completion state. (1) Each task notification (email, text, push) contains a direct deep link that opens to exactly the task, not to a dashboard or menu that requires navigation. 'Your Manhattan listing is ready to verify -- tap here (2 min).' (2) Each task screen presents exactly one decision with the minimum information needed to make it. Listing verification: summary card with 'Looks good' or 'Edit.' Pricing: one rate question per screen. Proposal review: proposal card with 'Accept,' 'Decline,' or 'Schedule Zoom.' (3) Every task auto-saves on any input, so interruption at any point loses no work. (4) For multi-property hosts, tasks are sequenced across properties rather than bundled: today verify Manhattan, tomorrow verify Queens Building 1, the day after Queens Building 2. Each notification is a complete, self-contained task. (5) The host's dashboard shows a simple task list with time estimates, so she can choose which 2-minute gap to fill with which task.

evidence.quote: It's unbelievable. You know, the day is never long enough.
evidence.insight: Diane's time constraint is permanent and structural. She will never have a 30-minute block to dedicate to platform setup. Every interaction must fit into the margins of her day -- waiting for a call, between property visits, during a commute.

evidence.quote: I have an apartment in Manhattan and I have two buildings in Queens.
evidence.insight: Three properties multiply every time cost. If each property requires one 15-minute session, the total is 45 minutes. If each requires three 2-minute tasks spread across days, the total is still 18 minutes but distributed into manageable gaps. Only the distributed pattern is compatible with Diane's schedule.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, How to Write a Persuasive Message
evidence.quote: System 2 is lazy and that mental effort is aversive. If possible, the recipients of your message want to stay away from anything that reminds them of effort.
evidence.insight: The mere perception of effort prevents task initiation. A notification that says 'Complete your listing setup' implies a long process and triggers avoidance. A notification that says 'Verify your Manhattan listing (2 min)' implies a short, bounded task and triggers action.

evidence.quote: Cognitive strain is experienced when the effortful operations of System 2 are engaged.
evidence.insight: Time poverty amplifies cognitive strain because there is no recovery time between tasks. A 2-minute task followed by a return to normal life allows full recovery. A 15-minute multi-step process compounds strain across each step with no relief, making each subsequent decision worse than the last.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the single decision the host needs to make right now. Secondary: the minimum context needed to make that decision (property name, key details, proposed values). Tertiary: links to full details, editing tools, or related tasks. The hierarchy is ruthlessly minimal: one action, supported by just enough information, with everything else available but not visible.
elements.disclosure_pattern: The notification contains: task name, property identifier, estimated time, and deep link. The deep-linked screen contains: the decision with pre-filled context and action buttons. Full details are expandable but never required for the primary action. Related tasks for other properties appear only after the current task is completed, never before.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 decision per screen. Maximum 2 minutes per task. Maximum 3 information elements needed to make the decision. All tasks auto-save. No multi-step wizards that require completion in one session. Task notifications include time estimates that never exceed '2 min.'
scan_order: Property identifier (which property is this about)
The decision to make (verify / set rate / accept-decline)
Key context for the decision (pre-filled values, summary)
Action buttons (confirm / edit / skip for now)
exclude: Dashboard navigation required before reaching the task
Multi-property tasks bundled into a single session by default
Progress bars implying a long process ahead
Tasks for other properties visible while the current task is incomplete
Any screen that requires more than one scroll on a phone to see the action buttons

elements.title: Agency-Preserving Invitation Architecture: Browse Before Activate, Explore Before Commit
elements.problem: Robert offers to pre-create Diane's account (10:07), but Diane explicitly pushes back: 'I want to read the whole website' (15:59). At 16:38 she asks 'What should I look for? What's the name of it?' -- revealing that after a 17-minute call, she does not even know the platform name well enough to find it independently. The platform has not yet achieved the mere-exposure familiarity threshold that Kahneman identifies as necessary for positive feelings. In this state of cognitive strain (unfamiliar platform, no prior exposure, novel business model), having an account pre-created without consent does not reduce strain -- it triggers the vigilance-and-suspicion cluster. The information architecture of the evaluation-to-onboarding transition must let the host browse, verify, and build familiarity before any account action is taken on her behalf.
elements.solution: Design the post-call landing experience as an explorable preview that requires zero commitment. (1) The agent sends a single link that opens a personalized, no-login-required preview page: 'Robert prepared this for you -- browse at your pace.' The page shows: the three guarantees in call language, a preview of what the host's imported listing would look like, and the agent's contact information. (2) The preview page is fully browsable without account creation. The host can explore the platform, read about the model, and verify claims from the call, all without logging in. (3) Only after the host has browsed does the page present a clear activation action: 'Ready to get started? Claim your account.' The language frames the host as the agent: she claims, she activates, she decides. Nothing has been created for her -- everything has been prepared for her to accept when ready. (4) The preview page uses the same language Robert used on the call, creating phrase-level recognition at first contact with the platform.

evidence.quote: You don't have to start the account. Anyway, if I want to, I want to read the whole website.
evidence.insight: Diane asserts control over the onboarding pace. She wants to verify before anything is done in her name. The information architecture must support this verification-first behavior pattern, not override it with pre-created accounts.

evidence.quote: What should I look for? What's the name of it?
evidence.insight: The platform has not achieved name-level familiarity after a 17-minute call. The first digital touchpoint must eliminate the search friction entirely: the agent sends the exact link, the page opens without login, and the host immediately sees content that echoes the call.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, The Pleasure of Cognitive Ease
evidence.quote: The mere exposure effect occurs because the repeated exposure of a stimulus is followed by nothing bad. Such a stimulus will eventually become a safety signal, and safety is good.
evidence.insight: The browsable preview is the host's first mere-exposure event with the platform's digital interface. If it produces cognitive ease (familiar language, no demands, no surprises), it becomes a positive exposure that builds toward the safety signal. If it demands login or account activation immediately, the first exposure is strained, and subsequent exposures carry that strain forward.

evidence.quote: When you feel strained, you are more likely to be vigilant and suspicious, invest more effort in what you are doing, feel less comfortable, and make fewer errors.
evidence.insight: Diane is in a strained state: evaluating an unfamiliar platform. Presenting a pre-created account to a strained user does not ease the strain -- it intensifies it by removing her sense of control. The architecture must let the strain resolve naturally through browsing and verification before introducing any commitment action.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: the call-language value propositions displayed on a no-login preview page. Secondary: explorable platform content (how it works, sample listings, model explanation). Tertiary: account activation action, presented only after the host has had opportunity to browse. The hierarchy inverts the typical onboarding pattern: instead of 'create account, then explore,' it is 'explore, then claim account.'
elements.disclosure_pattern: The agent's email/text contains one link. The link opens a personalized preview with no login required. The preview shows call-echoing content immediately. Platform exploration is available without authentication. The account activation prompt appears after the host has scrolled or browsed at least one section, never as the first element. Follow-up reminders use the same preview link, not a separate login link.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Zero decisions required on the preview page. The only action available is 'Claim your account' and it is optional. No forms, no fields, no required inputs until the host explicitly chooses to activate. The preview loads in under 3 seconds and requires no app download or account creation to view.
scan_order: Agent's name and personalized greeting ('Robert prepared this for you')
Preview of what the host's listing would look like (if import data available)
Account activation action (below the fold, after content)
exclude: Login forms or account creation prompts above the fold
Temporary passwords in the first communication
Pressure language ('Your account is waiting,' 'Complete your registration')
Feature lists or platform capabilities not discussed on the call
Time-limited offers or urgency cues ('Activate within 48 hours')
